Ref Table(s).0: HSE_INCIDENTHSE_INCIDENT_SUBSTANCEHSE_INCIDENT_RESPONSEHSE_INCIDENT_EQUIPHSE_INCIDENT_DETAILHSE_INCIDENT_CAUSEHSE_INCIDENT_BA

Column Comment.0: INCIDENT IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for an health safety or environment relatedincident.
Column Comment.1: INTERACTION OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique number that identifies theinteractions between details and responses, people and equipment. Each new set ofinteractions should be assigned a new number within the same incident.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: CAUSE OBS NO: a unique identifier for an incident cause. Some incidents may havemore than one cause, or a combination of causes.
Column Comment.4: DESCRIPTION: Narrative description of the interaction.
Column Comment.5: DETAIL OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique number for the detail about theconsequnce or result of the incident. A list of things that happened.
Column Comment.6: EFFECTIVE DATE: date on which the data in this row came into effect.
Column Comment.7: EQUIPMENT OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifier assigned to theequipment involved in an incident, not usually the EQUIPMENT ID. In some casesspecific pieces or kinds of equipment cannot be identified, although you may be ableto identify the type of equipment involved.
Column Comment.8: EQUIPMENT ROLE OBSERVATION NUMBER: Use this column to allow equipmentto carry more than one role in an incident. For example, a vehicle may be used toevacuate staff and to transport materials.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: Date on which the data in this row of data was no longer in effect.
Column Comment.10: REFERENCE HSE INCIDENT SUBSTANCE: Identifies any substance involved withan HSE incident. This may be a hydrocarbon, a drilling fluid, fire retardent etc.
Column Comment.11: INCIDENT INTERACTION TYPE: the type of interaction among components of anincident.
Column Comment.12: PARTY OBSERVATION NUMBER: An identifier for the party involved in the incident.Not a PK to the BUSINESS ASSOCIATE table because of privacy issues. In somecases, it is only possible to track the class (employee or consultant) of the partyinvolved in the incident.
Column Comment.13: PARTY ROLE OBSERVATION NUMBER: Use this column to allow a party to carrymore than one role in an incident. For example, the safety inspection officer may alsobe the first aid officer in the event of an injury.
Column Comment.14: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.15: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.16: RESPONSE OBS NO: a unique identifier for an action taken as a result of whathappened at an incident. For example, an ambulance may be called, a reprimandentered into a file etc. For details about the work flow related to actions, werecommend you use the PROJECTS module.
Column Comment.17: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.18: INCIDENT SUBSTANCE SEQ NO: Track the occurence of the substancerelationship to an incident.
Column Comment.19: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.20: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.21: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.22: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.23: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.24: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.25: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
